Description: Disables and stops the SQL Server Browser service on computers with no named instances
Author: Tracy Boggiano (@TracyBoggiano), databasesuperhero.com
Examples:
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
PS C:\>Disable-DbsBrowser -ComputerName sql2016, sql2019
Disables and stops the SQL Server Browser service on sql2016 and sql2019 if no named instances exist
Synopsis: Disables and stops the SQL Server Browser service on computers with no named instances
Name: Disable-DbsBrowser

Description: Disables all instances of CEIP on a server via both services and the registry (x64 and x86)

Description:
Gets the required permissions for SQL Server directories

By default, it will detect and secure the default Data, Log and Backup directories
Author: Chrissy LeMaire (@cl), netnerds.net
Examples:
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbsAcl -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012
Gets permissions for the default data, log and backups on sql2017, sql2016, sql2012
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbaRegServer -SqlInstance sqlcentral | Get-DbsAcl
Gets the permissions for all SQL Servers stored in the sqlcentral registered server
Params: The target SQL Server instance or instances

By default, the ACLs on the paths to the data, log and backup files will be modified.
If you want to set permissions on a specific path, use this option.
Note that if your Backup directory is a UNC share, it will be skipped.
Synopsis: Gets the permissions required by DISA for SQL Server directories
Name: Get-DbsAcl

Description: Installs the supplemental SQL Server Audit provided by DISA
Author: Chrissy LeMaire (@cl), netnerds.net
Examples:
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
PS C:\>Install-DbsAudit -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012
Detect version and create appropriate audit from DISA, output to DATA\Stig\, shutdown on failure
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Install-DbsAudit -SqlInstance sql2017 -SqlCredential sqladmin -Path C:\temp -OnFaiure Continue
Login as sqladmin, detect version and create appropriate audit from DISA, output to C:\temp, continue on failure
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbaRegServer -SqlInstance sqlcentral | Install-DbaDisaStigAudit
Installs disa stig on all servers on the CMS
Params: The target SQL Server instance or instances
The name of the audit and audit specification. Defaults to DISA's default of DISA_STIG.
The path where the audit files will be created. Defaults to default data directory + STIG. Creates the directory if it does not exist.
The max size of each audit file. Defaults to 10MB.
The max number of files to keep. Defaults to 50.
Sets the reserve of disk space. Defaults to OFF.
Sets the queue delay of the audit. Defaults to 1000.
Instructs SQL Server of what to do on failure. Defaults to SHUTDOWN. Options include 'FAIL_OPERATION', 'SHUTDOWN', 'CONTINUE'.
Synopsis: Installs the supplemental SQL Server Audit provided by DISA
Name: Install-DbsAudit

Description:
Removes non-compliant audit states

If you remove permissions for 'NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM' using this command and they continue to persist, check to ensure
that the permissions are not granted by a role such as sysadmin
Author: Chrissy LeMaire (@cl), netnerds.net
Examples:
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
PS C:\>Remove-DbsSystemPermission -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012
Gets a list of non-compliant audit states on sql2017, sql2016 and sql2012
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Remove-DbsSystemPermission -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016 and sql2012
Removes all non-compliant permissions for NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM on sql2017, sql2016 and sql2012
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbsSystemPermission -SqlInstance sql2014 | Out-GridView -PassThru | Remove-DbsSystemPermission
Gets a list of non-compliant permissions for NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM, prompts to select specific permissions, then removes the selected permissions
Params: The target SQL Server instance or instances
Synopsis: Remoes non-compliant audit states
Name: Remove-DbsSystemPermission

Description: Removes unauthorized users from roles and/or sets the owner of the database to an authorized login
Author: Chrissy LeMaire (@cl), netnerds.net
Examples:
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 | Remove-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole
Removes unauthorized users from their associated roles
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 | Remove-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole -Confirm:$false
Removes unauthorized users from their associated roles and does not prompt
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 | Out-GridView -Passthru | Remove-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole -Type SetOwner -NewOwner AD\chantel.phillip -Confirm:$false
Sets the owner of the database to an authorized login, AD\chantel.phillip
Params: Allows databases to be piped in from Get-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole

The type of repair - remove user from role, set a new db owner, or both
Options: "RemoveRoleMember", "SetOwner"
The type of repair - remove user from role, set a new db owner, or both
Synopsis: Removes unauthorized users from roles and/or sets the owner of the database to an authorized login
Name: Repair-DbsDbOwnerFixedServerRole

-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbsDbAlterPermission -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 | Out-GridView -Passthru | Revoke-DbsDbAlterPermission -Confirm:$false
Revokes _selected_ non-compliant alter permissions on sql2017, sql2016, sql2012, does not prompt
Params: Allows databases to be piped in from Get-DbsDbAlterPermission
Synopsis: Removes non-compliant alter permissions

Description:
Sets the required permissions for SQL Server directories

By default, it will detect and secure the default Data, Log and Backup directories
Author: Chrissy LeMaire (@cl), netnerds.net
Examples:
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
PS C:\>Set-DbsAcl -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 -Account "AD\SQL Admins" -Owner "AD\SQL Service"
Sets permissions for the default data, log and backups on sql2017, sql2016, sql2012
Adds appropriate permissions for the "AD\SQL Admins" group as well as the SQL Server service accountsas Full Access
Also sets the owner of the folder to "AD\SQL Service"
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Get-DbaRegServer -SqlInstance sqlcentral | Set-DbsAcl -Account "AD\SQL Admins" -Owner "AD\SQL Service"
Sets the appropriate permissions for all SQL Servers stored in the sqlcentral registered server
Params:
The target SQL Server instance or instances
This is required to get specific information about the paths to modify
The base computer name is also used to perform the actual modifications
The account that will be set as the folder owner
The account name or names that are to be granted permissions along with the service accounts

By default, the ACLs on the paths to the data, log and backup files will be modified
If you want to set permissions on a specific path, use this option
Note that if your Backup directory is a UNC share, it will be skipped
Synopsis: Sets the permissions required by DISA for SQL Server directories
Name: Set-DbsAcl

Description: Create the audit maintainer role, sets the permissions for the role, and adds logins

PS C:\>Set-DbsAuditMaintainer -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 -Login "AD\SQL Admins"

-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
PS C:\>Set-DbsAuditMaintainer -SqlInstance sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 -Role auditmaintainers -Login "AD\SQL Admins"
Set permissions for the auditmaintainers role on sql2017, sql2016, sql2012 for user AD\SQL Admins on Prod database.
Params: The target SQL Server instance or instances
Name to be given the audit maintainer role
The login or logins that are to be granted permissions. This should be a Windows Group or you may violate another STIG
Synopsis:
Create the audit maintainer role, sets the permissions for the role, and adds logins

NOTE! This command revokes permz.
